keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, 38, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and sentenced to between five years and life in prison for a first-degree felony.
Rossi faked his death in 2020 by claiming he had died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which was later found to be false based on evidence from Rhode Island and his former connections.

He evaded authorities for years by using multiple aliases, including claiming to be an Irish orphan named Arthur Knight, and was identified through a DNA match from a 2018 rape kit backlog initiative.
Rossi was arrested in Scotland in 2023 after hospital staff recognized his tattoos from an Interpol notice, leading to his extradition to Utah in January 2024.
The victim described the abuse as traumatic and lasting, emphasizing the need for accountability and safety, not vengeance.
Utah law allows a range of prison sentences for rape, and Rossi’s sentence is five years to life, with the parole board determining release timing.
Rossi’s legal name is Nicholas Alahverdian, and he has a history of sex-related offenses, including being previously convicted in Ohio and failing to register as a sex offender in Rhode Island.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, 38, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and sentenced to between five years and life in prison after being identified through a DNA match from a decade-old rape kit. He faked his death in 2020, claiming he died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and used multiple aliases—including Arthur Knight—to evade capture. Authorities in Rhode Island and Scotland raised concerns about his identity, and he was arrested in Scotland in 2023 after his tattoos were recognized from an Interpol notice. He was extradited to Utah in January 2024, where he faced sentencing after a trial in which his accuser and parents testified. A judge described him as a 'flight risk' and 'serial abuser,' and he maintained his innocence during sentencing. The case underscores the dangers of sexual predators evading justice through deception and the importance of DNA testing and international cooperation in solving long-standing crimes.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
